Posts.Content: JB22, your experience is not uncommon, maybe even closer to the norm. The first stage is being dry overnight - you are there. Bask in the positive of that. Over time you'll progress to being dry when seated, then when standing, then as you transition, and so it goes. 5 days out is real early to expect great continence. You'll hopefully see some fairly big improvements week on week over the first 6 weeks. Your doctor's advise on liquids is close but a bit misguided based on what my surgeon and local Uro both told me. Drink lots of liquids for sure. There are many bladder irritants, and any of them in your urine will cause your bladder to want to get rid of the urine. Making it tougher to control that lonely bladder sphyncter. The more you drink, the more you keep any of the irritants diluted. Some of the irritants to avoid include: - Uria. Yes, you by definition has urea in your urine. But the more dehydrated you are, the greater the concentration, thus why your urine gets yellower. Keeping well hydrated keeps the urea concetration down. Drink lots to keep your urine clear. - Caffiene. It's a diuretic and an irritant. Thus drinking tea is a bad idea if it has caffiene. Herbal teas are as the are not caffinated. Coke and other caffinated soda are also therefore unfriendly to your continence. - Alcohol. A double whamy. An irritant and a muscle relaxer. Just say no. Even when I was doing real well on continence, when I tested with a beer I had problems holding it. - Citric juices. They are irritants too. Orange juice and grapefruit juice are the worst offenders. Highly concentrated in citric acid. - Cranberry juice. I don't know why, must be the acids in it too. Just know they told me to stay away. So what can you drink - water, water, and more water. If you like juice, go with apple. Caffiene free soda if you like soda. As FLmlp mentions, do your Kegel exercises. The single greatest thing you can do at this point. Check out my post on Physical Therapy regimen. Careful not to overdo it until the muscle gets stronger. Overstressing the muscle will tire it out and make things worse. Build up slowly. At 50 years old you are young, this plays in your favor. This along with physical condition affect recovery as well. The stronger you came into RP, the better you'll do in gaining control back. You'll improve, give it time. You've had major surgery and the muscles and internal tissues have a lot of healing to go.

Posts.Title: Physical Therapy regimen with Kegels

Posts.Content: In a different thread FLmlp asked about Kegels and suggestions for help. I felt it would be better to post this in a new thread so others can more easily find it instead of burying it in a thread under another title. My Uro had me do one session with a PT that specializes in RP recovery a month prior to surgery. She used biofeedback to help me learn how to do a Kegel correctly which was important. Then once doing them correctly, here is the regimen transcibed exactly from the instruction sheet: 1) First for warmup and to develop strength: Squeeze pelvic floor muscles as strongly as you can (use the muscles as if you are trying to stop yuor urine stream), hold for count of 3, then let go all the way. Fully relax and breathe at the bottom Don't let your legs, buttocks or stomach muslces help the pelvic floor, it is a very subtle movement of the muscles between the tailbone in the back, the pelvic bone in the front, and the bones we sit on 2) For endurance Squeeze the pelvic floor muscles as firmly as you can, hold for a smooth, slow count of 10 (count out loud if it helps you breathe), then let go all the way. Posts.Content: Tom, your initial presentation is similar to mine. I am 49. PCP felt what he characterized as a 3mm mass on the right side and I had an elevated PSA. Urologist felt the same thing. Interestingly the MRI showed a tumor on the left side. Biopsy showed signifcant cancer in the base on both left and right side. What was most interesting was after the biopsy, the mass was never detectable again. I had 4 doctors do DRE's in the course of visits and none felt it again. The folks at Johns Hopkins did the longest DRE one can ever imagine and found nothing. Very weird. You'll want to get all the details of the biopsy from your Uro. Get a copy of the biopsy report. Gleason is the scale used to evaluate the aggressiveness of the cancer. The Gleason number and how it is composed (there is a difference between 3+4 vs 4+3 = 7) along with the number of positive cores and % of cancer in each are all germain to helping you select the best course of treatment for you. There is no one right answer. You need to evaluate all your options and select the answer best for you. Get a copy of Dr. Walsh's Surviving Prostate Cancer. This book will educate you big time and enable you to know what to ask and what it all means. Talk to lots of doctors to find the course of treatment you are most comfortable with such that you never look back afterwards. If you are interested in surgery, I can highly recommend Dr. Vipul Patel in Orlando. I live in Colorado and travelled to Orlando to go to who I felt was best for me. I'm 3 weeks post surgery and amazed at where I am at this point. He did a great job on the surgery, specially given the extensiveness of my cancer. His practice is fantastic with the patients. A very well run shop that takes great care of you. Preps you with all the info you need, classes, and long term rehab care. With the number of surgeries he does per week, one would think it would just be a factory and that is what I feared at first. It is anything but a factory. Impressive how they care for their patients. And he is only a couple hours away from you. There were men there that have driven up from Miami, so your distance is not a problem. Google him, you'll find him on the web. Quite self promoting, but I found him to be excellent and the self promoting to not be far off.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club no-one wants to join, but glad you found us. As FLmlp mentions, Dr. Walsh's book is a must read. It will educate you on all your treatment options. Posts.Content: What you are experiencing is pretty common. You are hyper aware of everything now. It is tough to relax when you don't know what's going on. Definately read Dr. Walsh's book, and if you can before the Uro visit, go for it. While it is big and thick, I read it in a weekend because I wanted the knowledge. Knowledge is you best friend right now. It will enable you to understand what the doctors are saying, and better yet as the questions you want to know about. Most likely the Uro is going to recommend a biopsy. With the high PSA, that pretty likely in your future. Though doing a round of antibiotics is a good step to ensure the issue is not from something else (though that high a PSA, I'm sorry to say, has a pretty high likelihood of being PCa). Another test to discuss with the doctors is PCA-3. It is done from a urine sample after a DRE. So no pain, no medical intervention into your body. It gives a reading on the likelihood of PCa. That helps in deciding if a biopsy is a right next step. Another would be a Free PSA which is a blood test. If both these come back with high probability of PCa, you'll want to do the biopsy to know what you are dealing with. Yes, you are correct that PCa is usually slow growing, so a PSA velocity as you have is unusual. That does not mean the world is collapsing and even if it is PCa that you can't be treated. The first step is to find out what you are dealing with. Then go from there. Take a deep breath, read lots to learn, then dive in with some good doctors.

Some come out of the surgery totally continent (the lucky few), others with absolutely no urinary control (the unlucky few). Most land somewhere in the middle, improve over time, and what the final state will be is so person by person dependent. In my case, I met the medical standard for "continent" (which is less than 1 pad per day needed) the day after catheter removal. 5 days after catheter removal I no longer needed any protection. I just get 1 or 2 tiny dribbles in a day during weird muscle motions such as yawning, laughing, or moving in a funky way while seated. If you are not continent during non-active times, it will not be any better during running. Likely a little worse. Depending on how much flow you have, just wearing a pad (which is no big deal) may be sufficient. Again, your mileage may vary. Posts.Content: TKI - As others have said, at 39 PCa is much less likely, but always a possibility. Did you by chance have sexual activity the night before the PSA test or even within 48 hours. That will cause a higher PSA. An infection could, Prostatitus can, so many reasons. So at this point, it is not yet time to start thinking PCa. Some people have physical signs of PCa such as pain in lower back or other areas, others do not. So you pains are not necessarily indicative of PCa either. PCa is a very slow grower. IF (big IF) you were to have PCa, the 6 weeks your doctor suggests waiting for the next PSA will have no affect on the state of the cancer. So don't worry about the lost time there. The Cipro can address an infection, but not always. Different infections respond to different antibiotics. Cipro is pretty broad spectrum, but won't kill all. So it is not unheard of to still have whatever you had after Cipro if you have one. I'd suggest giving it the 6 weeks, abstain from sexual activity and bicyclying at least 48 hours before the test, and do the next PSA test. If that comes up high, have the Urologist do a Free PSA. It is another good blood test that gives more statistical probability of having PCa. There are others such as PCA3 though I'm not familiar with them. Let the blood work indicate if you need a biopsy. You don't have to just immediately jump into the biopsy. I did as you are doing and gave it the 6 week period then did multiple tests before choosing biopsy. The biopsy is relatively simple, but there are risks with any procedure, so don't take it lightly, ensure you want it before you do it.

Posts.Content: You've gotten great insights from the posts above so I won't rehash what they say. I'll toss a few more things in as well. I was given a leg bag and expected I'd be switching between the big bag and the smaller leg bag and never did. The hospital put the bag in something similar to a fabric shopping bag with a handle. I took a strap from a duffle and added it to the shopping bag loop and threw it over my shoulder. The shopping bag then hung just below waist line which was perfect. I had the hose come out the waist band of my sweat pants and right into the shopping bag. Walking around was no issue in this configuration. People could not even see the hose. Just looked like I had a shopping bag on my shoulder. With this, I never felt the need to switch to the leg bag which is nice as I did not have to do any of the cleaning associated with the transition. Wear boxers, not briefs. I've never done boxers so my wife ran out and bought some. That gives plenty of room for the hose to casually float where it needs to go without tugging which would be bad. The hospital gave me antibiotic ointment and instructed to put some on the tip of the penis where the catheter comes out. Kept everyting from getting sore. So no pain was had. Just a little uncomfortable due to the whole setup. Sleeping was easy, no issue. Just put the bag on the floor (in it's shopping bag) and slept like normal. One person mentioned the blood clots. There will be some in the first day or two, don't worry, that is normal. Catheter removal is a non-event. No pain, quick and over with. And you are so happy to get it out. Ask the doctor if they will provide you with pads or diaper or if you need to bring them. After a day you'll know if you are flowing or just leaking, i.e. do you need diaper or just pads. If just pads, go to briefs, boxers are way to loose. Some people come away after catheter removal being dry, but that is the rare exception. I flowed like a faucet for about 3 hours, then it slowed. I was dry overnight the first night (though wore a diaper as I did not know what to expect) and was less than a pad leakage starting that first day. I'm now 3 weeks post surgery and pretty much dry. I have not worn a pad since 5 days after catheter removal. Only get the rare occasional drip when I laugh. Each person is different, your mileage will absolutely vary. Good luck with the surgery. You'll be surprised the pain afterwards is far less than you might expect, you are up and about that night and walking OK by the next day, just guarded due to abdominal discomfort from the surgery and this hose hangin out where you never would want to see one. That all goes by pretty quickly. If you would like to talk with someone to explore more questions or experience, I'm happy to jump on the phone. Posts.Content: flody1 - my temp spiked to 103.5 the night after the biopsy and I could not control body temp. I was shivering uncontrollably, even in a warm bed then bath tub. Ended up spending 3 days in the hospital with sepsus (blood infection) from e.coli in the blood. A gift of the biopsy. I'm guessing you may have an infection, but hopefully just a UTI and they can deal with it with oral antibiotics. I'm surprised the Uro only had you do a few days. If they suspect an infection, which they obviously do given they gave you antibiotics, it is usually a couple week course of meds to kill it. Watch your temp carefully after you finish the meds. If it comes back up, talk with them immediately. Hope all is doing better for you now and it all goes away. It's nice to have that negative biopsy, and hopefully you don't have PCa. However as others have said, that elevated PSA is an indicator of something going wrong. Make sure your Uro gets to the bottom of it. You may only have a small volume of cancer and the needle biopsy did not hit the spot. At least if that is the case, it is very early and easily treatable should it show up in a biopsy in the future. If it were me, I'd be watching that PSA closely. Do another one 3 months or at most 6 months and see if it keeps rising. No sense doing one shortly after a biopsy, it will be falsely high. I had a Medical Oncologist do one 2 weeks after biopsy and it was 8.0. All other doctors said it was a silly thing to do because it would be known to be high and of no value. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Da Vinci robotic prostatectomy recovery--the first weeks after surgery--advice wanted

Posts.Content: w0rried, we are not doctors so please take any guidance we provide with that recognition. Folks here will offer from our experience and knowledge. I personally do not know much about BHP to answer you questions directly. What I would offer is that with a PSA of >100, though you don't want to hear it, it is quite likely there is Prostate Cancer involved. My understanding is BHP will elevate the PSA a good bit, but not to that level. Prostate cancer is not always felt in the DRE. That fact that his DRE found nothing is good. If something is felt, it can mean the disease is that much more advanced. In my case, 2 doctors detected a 3mm mass in the DRE. Yet my cancer appears have still been Prostate organ contained. So every case is different. The true indicator is the results of the biopsy. That tells you if there is cancer there, and at least the aggressiveness (Gleason score) and nature (how widely spread, how much in each core, etc.). The biopsy results, should they come up positive, can also be used to give a first glance at what the likelihood of spread beyond the Prostate would be based statistics from years and 10's of thousands of men. There is no direct answer, just statistical data. Should his biopsy come up positive, he'll have a lot of learning to do to figure out what course of treatment is best for him. Again there is no one answer, please do not let one doctor call the shots. Have him do his research, learn, talk to many specialists, and make his own decision. An excellent book to start with is Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is a must read for anyone dealing with this stuff. Again, IF his biopsy comes up positive, post the details of the results here and we can offer many good suggestions on how to proceed. One good news piece is that Prostate Cancer tends to be slow growing, so people have time to do their research and make the best decision for them. Here's to hoping the biopsy comes out negative for Prostate Cancer and you can look to what other causes might be there to resolve the issues ! Let us know what you find out. Best of luck to you and your uncle.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by w0rried Assuming if the original enlargement might have started several years back, unnoticed. Possible? That is not only possible but likely. Prostate Cancer is slow growing. IF he has PCa, with a PSA of 100, it is likely it's been growing for many years. My PSA was 4.5 (normal size prostate) and they estimate based on the quantity and type of cancer that it was growing for 5 years. I had regular PSA tests, they just were not indicative of cancer. Part of the nature and variety in this disease. As others have noted, as hard as it is, relax, wait for the biopsy, then IF it is positive you can deal with it in a careful and methodical manner. There is no hurry with this stuff unless it is so advanced into the bones and such. At your uncle's age there are numerous treatment choices which can give an excellent outcome (albeit each with their own side effects, understand them carefully) for longevity of life. I'm 49, I plan to live a long full happy life.
